line: full ripe: now we speak upon our cue, and our voice

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: is imperial: England shall repent his folly, see

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: his weakness, and admire our sufferance. Bid him

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: therefore consider of his ransom; which must

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: have lost, the disgrace we have digested; which in

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: weight to re-answer, his pettiness would bow under.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for the

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: person, kneeling at our feet, but a weak and

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: worthless satisfaction. To this add defiance: and

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: tell him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: followers, whose condemnation is pronounced. So far

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: my king and master; so much my office.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What is thy name? I know thy quality.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: Montjoy.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Thou dost thy office fairly. Turn thee back.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And tell thy king I do not seek him now;

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But could be willing to march on to Calais

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Without impeachment: for, to say the sooth,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Though 'tis no wisdom to confess so much

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Unto an enemy of craft and vantage,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My people are with sickness much enfeebled,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My numbers lessened, and those few I have

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Almost no better than so many French;

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Who when they were in health, I tell thee, herald,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I thought upon one pair of English legs

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Did march three Frenchmen. Yet, forgive me, God,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That I do brag thus! This your air of France

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Hath blown that vice in me: I must repent.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Go therefore, tell thy master here I am;

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My ransom is this frail and worthless trunk,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My army but a weak and sickly guard;

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Yet, God before, tell him we will come on,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Though France himself and such another neighbour

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Stand in our way. There's for thy labour, Montjoy.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Go bid thy master well advise himself:

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: If we may pass, we will; if we be hinder'd,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We shall your tawny ground with your red blood

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Discolour: and so Montjoy, fare you well.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The sum of all our answer is but this:

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We would not seek a battle, as we are;

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Nor, as we are, we say we will not shun it:

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: So tell your master.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: MONTJOY
line: I shall deliver so. Thanks to your highness.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: I hope they will not come upon us now.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We are in God's hand, brother, not in theirs.

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: March to the bridge; it now draws toward night:

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Beyond the river we'll encamp ourselves,

scene: SCENE VI.  The English camp in Picardy.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And on to-morrow, bid them march away.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Tut! I have the best armour of the world. Would it were day!

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: You have an excellent armour; but let my horse have his due.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: It is the best horse of Europe.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Will it never be morning?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: My lord of Orleans, and my lord high constable, you

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: talk of horse and armour?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: What a long night is this! I will not change my

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: horse with any that treads but on four pasterns.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Ca, ha! he bounds from the earth, as if his

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: entrails were hairs; le cheval volant, the Pegasus,

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: chez les narines de feu! When I bestride him, I

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: soar, I am a hawk: he trots the air; the earth

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: sings when he touches it; the basest horn of his

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: He's of the colour of the nutmeg.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Perseus: he is pure air and fire; and the dull

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: elements of earth and water never appear in him, but

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: only in Patient stillness while his rider mounts

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: him: he is indeed a horse; and all other jades you

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: may call beasts.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: It is the prince of palfreys; his neigh is like the

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: bidding of a monarch and his countenance enforces homage.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: No more, cousin.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: deserved praise on my palfrey: it is a theme as

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: fluent as the sea: turn the sands into eloquent

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: tongues, and my horse is argument for them all:

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: 'tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: a sovereign's sovereign to ride on; and for the

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: world, familiar to us and unknown to lay apart

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: their particular functions and wonder at him. I

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus:

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: 'Wonder of nature,'--

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: I have heard a sonnet begin so to one's mistress.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Then did they imitate that which I composed to my

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: courser, for my horse is my mistress.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Your mistress bears well.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Me well; which is the prescript praise and

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: perfection of a good and particular mistress.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: shook your back.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: So perhaps did yours.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Mine was not bridled.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: O then belike she was old and gentle; and you rode,

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off, and in

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: your straight strossers.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: You have good judgment in horsemanship.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so and ride

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: my horse to my mistress.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I had as lief have my mistress a jade.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: I tell thee, constable, my mistress wears his own hair.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I could make as true a boast as that, if I had a sow

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: to my mistress.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: 'Le chien est retourne a son propre vomissement, et

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: la truie lavee au bourbier;' thou makest use of any thing.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: such proverb so little kin to the purpose.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: My lord constable, the armour that I saw in your tent

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: to-night, are those stars or suns upon it?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Stars, my lord.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Some of them will fall to-morrow, I hope.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: And yet my sky shall not want.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: 'twere more honour some were away.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Even as your horse bears your praises; who would

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: trot as well, were some of your brags dismounted.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: it never be day? I will trot to-morrow a mile, and

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: my way shall be paved with English faces.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: my way: but I would it were morning; for I would

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: fain be about the ears of the English.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: You must first go yourself to hazard, ere you have them.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: 'Tis midnight; I'll go arm myself.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: The Dauphin longs for morning.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: He longs to eat the English.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I think he will eat all he kills.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: By the white hand of my lady, he's a gallant prince.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: He is simply the most active gentleman of France.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Doing is activity; and he will still be doing.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: He never did harm, that I heard of.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Nor will do none to-morrow: he will keep that good name still.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: I know him to be valiant.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I was told that by one that knows him better than

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: you.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: What's he?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: not who knew it

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: He needs not; it is no hidden virtue in him.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: By my faith, sir, but it is; never any body saw it

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: but his lackey: 'tis a hooded valour; and when it

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: appears, it will bate.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Ill will never said well.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: I will cap that proverb with 'There is flattery in friendship.'

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: And I will take up that with 'Give the devil his due.'

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Well placed: there stands your friend for the

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: devil: have at the very eye of that proverb with 'A

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: pox of the devil.'

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: You are the better at proverbs, by how much 'A

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: fool's bolt is soon shot.'

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: You have shot over.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: 'Tis not the first time you were overshot.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Messenger
line: My lord high constable, the English lie within

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Messenger
line: fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Who hath measured the ground?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Messenger
line: The Lord Grandpre.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: A valiant and most expert gentleman. Would it were

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: day! Alas, poor Harry of England! he longs not for

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: the dawning as we do.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: England, to mope with his fat-brained followers so

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: far out of his knowledge!

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: That they lack; for if their heads had any

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: intellectual armour, they could never wear such heavy

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: head-pieces.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: That island of England breeds very valiant

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: RAMBURES
line: creatures; their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Russian bear and have their heads crushed like

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: rotten apples! You may as well say, that's a

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: their wits with their wives: and then give them

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: eat like wolves and fight like devils.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: Then shall we find to-morrow they have only stomachs

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm:

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: Constable
line: come, shall we about it?

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: It is now two o'clock: but, let me see, by ten

scene: SCENE VII.  The French camp, near Agincourt:
speaker: ORLEANS
line: We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Gloucester, 'tis true that we are in great danger;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The greater therefore should our courage be.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Good morrow, brother Bedford. God Almighty!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: There is some soul of goodness in things evil,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Would men observingly distil it out.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: For our bad neighbour makes us early stirrers,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Which is both healthful and good husbandry:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Besides, they are our outward consciences,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And make a moral of the devil himself.

line: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham:

line: A good soft pillow for that good white head

line: Were better than a churlish turf of France.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: ERPINGHAM
line: Not so, my liege: this lodging likes me better,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: Since I may say 'Now lie I like a king.'

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: 'Tis good for men to love their present pains

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Upon example; so the spirit is eased:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And when the mind is quicken'd, out of doubt,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The organs, though defunct and dead before,

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Break up their drowsy grave and newly move,

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: With casted slough and fresh legerity.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas. Brothers both,

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Commend me to the princes in our camp;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Do my good morrow to them, and anon

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Desire them an to my pavilion.

speaker: KING HENRY V

line: Go with my brothers to my lords of England:

line: And then I would no other company.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!

line: God-a-mercy, old heart! thou speak'st cheerfully.

line: A friend.

speaker: PISTOL

line: I am a gentleman of a company.

speaker: PISTOL
line: Trail'st thou the puissant pike?

line: Even so. What are you?

speaker: PISTOL
line: As good a gentleman as the emperor.

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Then you are a better than the king.

speaker: PISTOL
line: The king's a bawcock, and a heart of gold,

speaker: PISTOL
line: A lad of life, an imp of fame;

speaker: PISTOL
line: Of parents good, of fist most valiant.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: PISTOL
line: I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heart-string

line: I love the lovely bully. What is thy name?

line: Tell him, I'll knock his leek about his pate

line: Upon Saint Davy's day.

speaker: PISTOL

line: Captain Fluellen!

line: So! in the name of Jesu Christ, speak lower. It is

speaker: FLUELLEN
line: the greatest admiration of the universal world, when

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: FLUELLEN
line: the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the

speaker: FLUELLEN
line: wars is not kept: if you would take the pains but to

speaker: FLUELLEN
line: you shall find the ceremonies of the wars, and the

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: FLUELLEN
line: cares of it, and the forms of it, and the sobriety

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: FLUELLEN
line: of it, and the modesty of it, to be otherwise.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: GOWER
line: Why, the enemy is loud; you hear him all night.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: FLUELLEN
line: If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: FLUELLEN
line: coxcomb? in your own conscience, now?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: GOWER
line: I will speak lower.

speaker: FLUELLEN
line: I pray you and beseech you that you will.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Though it appear a little out of fashion,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: There is much care and valour in this Welshman.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: breaks yonder?

line: A friend.

line: Under what captain serve you?

line: Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: A good old commander and a most kind gentleman: I

line: pray you, what thinks he of our estate?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: washed off the next tide.

line: He hath not told his thought to the king?

line: No; nor it is not meet he should. For, though I

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man; and

line: though his affections are higher mounted than ours,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: yet, when they stoop, they stoop with the like

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V

line: where he is.

line: them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their

line: children rawly left. I am afeard there are few die

line: well that die in a battle; for how can they

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: subjection.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

speaker: KING HENRY V

speaker: KING HENRY V

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V

speaker: KING HENRY V

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: have before gored the gentle bosom of peace with

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.

line: I embrace it.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: How shall I know thee again?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear it in my

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: bonnet: then, if ever thou darest acknowledge it, I

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: will make it my quarrel.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: Here's my glove: give me another of thine.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: There.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: This will I also wear in my cap: if ever thou come

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: to me and say, after to-morrow, 'This is my glove,'

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: by this hand, I will take thee a box on the ear.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: Thou darest as well be hanged.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Well. I will do it, though I take thee in the

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: king's company.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: WILLIAMS
line: Keep thy word: fare thee well.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: BATES
line: Be friends, you English fools, be friends: we have

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: BATES
line: French quarrels enow, if you could tell how to reckon.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: one, they will beat us; for they bear them on their

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: shoulders: but it is no English treason to cut

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: French crowns, and to-morrow the king himself will

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: be a clipper.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Upon the king! let us our lives, our souls,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Our debts, our careful wives,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Our children and our sins lay on the king!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We must bear all. O hard condition,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Of every fool, whose sense no more can feel

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But his own wringing! What infinite heart's-ease

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Must kings neglect, that private men enjoy!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And what have kings, that privates have not too,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Save ceremony, save general ceremony?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And what art thou, thou idle ceremony?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What kind of god art thou, that suffer'st more

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What are thy rents? what are thy comings in?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: O ceremony, show me but thy worth!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What is thy soul of adoration?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Art thou aught else but place, degree and form,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Creating awe and fear in other men?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Wherein thou art less happy being fear'd

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Than they in fearing.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What drink'st thou oft, instead of homage sweet,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But poison'd flattery? O, be sick, great greatness,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Think'st thou the fiery fever will go out

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: With titles blown from adulation?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Will it give place to flexure and low bending?

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Canst thou, when thou command'st the beggar's knee,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Command the health of it? No, thou proud dream,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That play'st so subtly with a king's repose;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I am a king that find thee, and I know

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: 'Tis not the balm, the sceptre and the ball,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The sword, the mace, the crown imperial,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The intertissued robe of gold and pearl,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The farced title running 'fore the king,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That beats upon the high shore of this world,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: No, not all these, thrice-gorgeous ceremony,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Not all these, laid in bed majestical,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Can sleep so soundly as the wretched slave,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Who with a body fill'd and vacant mind

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Gets him to rest, cramm'd with distressful bread;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Never sees horrid night, the child of hell,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But, like a lackey, from the rise to set

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Sweats in the eye of Phoebus and all night

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Sleeps in Elysium; next day after dawn,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And follows so the ever-running year,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: With profitable labour, to his grave:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And, but for ceremony, such a wretch,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Had the fore-hand and vantage of a king.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The slave, a member of the country's peace,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Enjoys it; but in gross brain little wots

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What watch the king keeps to maintain the peace,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Whose hours the peasant best advantages.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: ERPINGHAM
line: My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: ERPINGHAM
line: Seek through your camp to find you.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Good old knight,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Collect them all together at my tent:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I'll be before thee.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: ERPINGHAM
line: I shall do't, my lord.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: O God of battles! steel my soldiers' hearts;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Possess them not with fear; take from them now

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The sense of reckoning, if the opposed numbers

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Pluck their hearts from them. Not to-day, O Lord,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: O, not to-day, think not upon the fault

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My father made in compassing the crown!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I Richard's body have interred anew;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And on it have bestow'd more contrite tears

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Than from it issued forced drops of blood:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Who twice a-day their wither'd hands hold up

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Toward heaven, to pardon blood; and I have built

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Two chantries, where the sad and solemn priests

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Sing still for Richard's soul. More will I do;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Though all that I can do is nothing worth,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Since that my penitence comes after all,

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Imploring pardon.

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: My liege!

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My brother Gloucester's voice? Ay;

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I know thy errand, I will go with thee:

scene: SCENE I.  The English camp at Agincourt.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The day, my friends and all things stay for me.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: ORLEANS
line: The sun doth gild our armour; up, my lords!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Montez A cheval! My horse! varlet! laquais! ha!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: ORLEANS
line: O brave spirit!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Via! les eaux et la terre.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: ORLEANS
line: Rien puis? L'air et la feu.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Ciel, cousin Orleans.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Now, my lord constable!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Hark, how our steeds for present service neigh!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Mount them, and make incision in their hides,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: That their hot blood may spin in English eyes,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: And dout them with superfluous courage, ha!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: RAMBURES
line: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: RAMBURES
line: How shall we, then, behold their natural tears?

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Messenger
line: The English are embattled, you French peers.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: To horse, you gallant princes! straight to horse!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Do but behold yon poor and starved band,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: And your fair show shall suck away their souls,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Leaving them but the shales and husks of men.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: There is not work enough for all our hands;

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: To give each naked curtle-axe a stain,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: That our French gallants shall to-day draw out,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: And sheathe for lack of sport: let us but blow on them,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: The vapour of our valour will o'erturn them.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: 'Tis positive 'gainst all exceptions, lords,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Who in unnecessary action swarm

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: About our squares of battle, were enow

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: To purge this field of such a hilding foe,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Though we upon this mountain's basis by

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: Took stand for idle speculation:

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: But that our honours must not. What's to say?

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: A very little little let us do.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: The tucket sonance and the note to mount;

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: For our approach shall so much dare the field

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: That England shall couch down in fear and yield.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Yon island carrions, desperate of their bones,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Ill-favouredly become the morning field:

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: And our air shakes them passing scornfully:

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggar'd host

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps:

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: With torch-staves in their hand; and their poor jades

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Lob down their heads, dropping the hides and hips,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: The gum down-roping from their pale-dead eyes

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: And in their pale dull mouths the gimmal bit

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Lies foul with chew'd grass, still and motionless;

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: And their executors, the knavish crows,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Fly o'er them, all impatient for their hour.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: Description cannot suit itself in words

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: To demonstrate the life of such a battle

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: GRANDPRE
line: In life so lifeless as it shows itself.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: And give their fasting horses provender,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: DAUPHIN
line: And after fight with them?

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: I stay but for my guidon: to the field!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: I will the banner from a trumpet take,

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: And use it for my haste. Come, come, away!

scene: SCENE II.  The French camp.
speaker: Constable
line: The sun is high, and we outwear the day.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: GLOUCESTER
line: Where is the king?

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: BEDFORD
line: The king himself is rode to view their battle.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: Of fighting men they have full three score thousand.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: EXETER
line: There's five to one; besides, they all are fresh.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: God's arm strike with us! 'tis a fearful odds.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: God be wi' you, princes all; I'll to my charge:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: If we no more meet till we meet in heaven,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: Then, joyfully, my noble Lord of Bedford,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: My dear Lord Gloucester, and my good Lord Exeter,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: And my kind kinsman, warriors all, adieu!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: BEDFORD
line: Farewell, good Salisbury; and good luck go with thee!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: EXETER
line: Farewell, kind lord; fight valiantly to-day:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: EXETER
line: And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: EXETER
line: For thou art framed of the firm truth of valour.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: BEDFORD
line: He is full of valour as of kindness;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: BEDFORD
line: Princely in both.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: O that we now had here

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: But one ten thousand of those men in England

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: That do no work to-day!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What's he that wishes so?

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: My cousin Westmoreland? No, my fair cousin:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: If we are mark'd to die, we are enow

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: To do our country loss; and if to live,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The fewer men, the greater share of honour.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: God's will! I pray thee, wish not one man more.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: By Jove, I am not covetous for gold,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: It yearns me not if men my garments wear;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Such outward things dwell not in my desires:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But if it be a sin to covet honour,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: I am the most offending soul alive.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: God's peace! I would not lose so great an honour

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: As one man more, methinks, would share from me

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: For the best hope I have. O, do not wish one more!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Rather proclaim it, Westmoreland, through my host,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That he which hath no stomach to this fight,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Let him depart; his passport shall be made

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And crowns for convoy put into his purse:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We would not die in that man's company

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That fears his fellowship to die with us.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: This day is called the feast of Crispian:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: He that outlives this day, and comes safe home,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Will stand a tip-toe when the day is named,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And rouse him at the name of Crispian.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: He that shall live this day, and see old age,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbours,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And say 'To-morrow is Saint Crispian:'

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.'

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But he'll remember with advantages

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: What feats he did that day: then shall our names.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Familiar in his mouth as household words

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Harry the king, Bedford and Exeter,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Be in their flowing cups freshly remember'd.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: This story shall the good man teach his son;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: From this day to the ending of the world,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But we in it shall be remember'd;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: For he to-day that sheds his blood with me

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: This day shall gentle his condition:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And gentlemen in England now a-bed

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Shall think themselves accursed they were not here,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: That fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed:

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: The French are bravely in their battles set,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: SALISBURY
line: And will with all expedience charge on us.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: All things are ready, if our minds be so.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: God's will! my liege, would you and I alone,

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: WESTMORELAND
line: Without more help, could fight this royal battle!

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Why, now thou hast unwish'd five thousand men;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Which likes me better than to wish us one.

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: You know your places: God be with you all!

speaker: MONTJOY

line: I pray thee, bear my former answer back:

line: Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Good God! why should they mock poor fellows thus?

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: The man that once did sell the lion's skin

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: A many of our bodies shall no doubt

speaker: KING HENRY V

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Let me speak proudly: tell the constable

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: We are but warriors for the working-day;

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirch'd

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: With rainy marching in the painful field;

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: There's not a piece of feather in our host--

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: Good argument, I hope, we will not fly--

speaker: KING HENRY V

scene: SCENE III.  The English camp.
speaker: KING HENRY V
line: But, by the mass, our hearts are in the trim;

speaker: KING HENRY V
line: And my poor soldiers tell me, yet ere night

line: They'll be in fresher robes, or they will pluck
